SENT.plain: BACKGROUND: Rectal tumors are rare in childhood and among them malignant tumors are even less common
Only eight cases of primary rectal lymphomas were reported in children, with various presenting signs and histology
Burkitt's lymphomas are among these cases
CASE REPORT: A five-year-old child presented with hematochezia and unusual constipation
The rectal examination showed a voluminous intra rectal mass
Radiographic and pathologic examinations led to the diagnostic of Burkitt's lymphoma with medullary involvement
Complete remission was obtained after initial chemotherapy but a local relapse occurred and the child died eight months later
CONCLUSION: Hematochezia associated with unusual constipation impose a rectal examination
Early diagnosis of a rectal tumor may allow patients survival
